Screen.title: TopScreen
Screen.Label: ---------- Mouse Button 1 click on field to change ----------

Help.Tip: Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
Help.Text:
ranline - PROCESSDEFAULTS
Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
 
 Default = SYSTEM
 Allowed = SYSTEM
 Allowed = PROJECT
 Allowed = USER
 SYSTEM defaults are the defaults listed in the CPS documentation.
 
 PROJECT defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as Project
 Default button.
 
 USER defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as User Default
 button.

Screen.title: RANLINE Process
Screen.Label: 3D trace interpolation to random lines
NUM_TRACES=
Max # input traces to use altogether.
WIN_LEN =
Semblance window length for dip search (seconds).
MAX_SEARCH=
Maximum # traces to use for dip search.
MAX_INTERP=
Maximum # traces to interpolate or mix.
FRACMIX =
Fractional mix performed (0 to 1.414).
FEET_OUT =
Output trace spacing along random lines (feet or meters).
HDR_X =
HDR_Y =
Header word.
DIP_MAX_X=
DIP_MAX_Y=
Maximum dip (ms / unit hwd value).
dip_inc_x=
dip_inc_y=
Dip increment (ms / unit hwd value).
nxdips =
nydips =
Total number of dips.
SEARCH_X =
SEARCH_Y =
Maximum search distance (hwd units).
FEET_X =
FEET_Y =
Unit size of hwd value (feet or meters).

Help.Tip: Total number of input traces to be used.
Help.Text:
ranline - NUM_TRACES
Total number of input traces to be used.
 
 Default = 99999
 Allowed = int > 0
 
 This is the total number of input traces that will be used for generating
 the output traces.  It usually will be much smaller than the number of
 input traces.  This number can be approximate since it is used only for
 reserving disk space.

Help.Tip: Length of the time window, in sec, for the semblance calculation.
Help.Text:
ranline - WIN_LEN
Length of the time window, in sec, for the semblance calculation.
 
 Default = 0.1
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 
 WIN_LEN is used for dip search calculations prior to generating mixed traces.

Help.Tip: Maximum number of traces to use for dip search.
Help.Text:
ranline - MAX_SEARCH
Maximum number of traces to use for dip search.
 
 Default = 8
 Allowed = int >= MAX_INTERP
 
 Maximum number of traces to use for dip searching for a given output
 trace.  If DIP_MAX_X and DIP_MAX_Y are both zero, no dip search and
 adjustment will be done.

Help.Tip: Maximum number of traces to use for interpolating.
Help.Text:
ranline - MAX_INTERP
Maximum number of traces to use for interpolating.
 
 Default = 4
 Allowed = int >= 1
 
 Maximum number of traces to use to interpolate a given output trace.
 If MAX_INTERP = 1, the nearest trace to the trace output location will
 be used.

Help.Tip: Fractional mix performed during interpolation.
Help.Text:
ranline - FRACMIX
Fractional mix performed during interpolation.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real 0.0 to 1.414
 
 The value 0 means a minimum amount of mixing is done, with all weights
 inversely proportional to distance from the trace output location,
 defined as SQRT([DX/SEARCH_X]**2+[DY/SEARCH_Y]**2).  This is
 appropriate for straight interpolation.
 
 The value 1.414 or larger means all traces used for interpolation will
 be weighted equally, regardless of their distances from the interpolated
 trace output location.  This would be a strong mix (equal-weight stack
 along dips) rather than an interpolation.
 
 For example, FRACMIX=0.3 means that all traces within distance 0.3 will
 have a weight corresponding to distance 0.3 (rather than a larger weight).
 This would be appropriate if you want to do some mixing while
 interpolating, so that an individual trace that may happen to lie at the
 trace output location will not get all the weight.

Help.Tip: Output trace spacing along random lines in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
ranline - FEET_OUT
Output trace spacing along random lines in feet or meters.
 
 Default = nil
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Header word containing the X coordinate.
Help.Text:
ranline - HDR_X
Header word containing the X coordinate.
 
 Default = 7
 Allowed = 1 - NWIH

Help.Tip: Header word containing the Y coordinate.
Help.Text:
ranline - HDR_Y
Header word containing the Y coordinate.
 
 Default = 8
 Allowed = 1 - NWIH

Help.Tip: Maximum dip in X direction to use in the dip search calculation.
Help.Text:
ranline - DIP_MAX_X
Maximum dip in X direction to use in the dip search calculation.
 
 Default = 10.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 
 Dips are in ms/trace in the X direction.
 
 A total of (2*DIP_X/DIP_INC_X + 1) dips are tested in the X direction,
 from -DIP_MAX_X to +DIP_MAX_X.
 
 Computer time is roughly proportional to the number of dips tested in the
 X direction times the number of dips tested in the Y direction.

Help.Tip: Maximum dip in Y direction to use in the dip search calculation.
Help.Text:
ranline - DIP_MAX_Y
Maximum dip in Y direction to use in the dip search calculation.
 
 Default = 10.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 
 Dips are in ms/trace in the Y direction.
 
 A total of (2*DIP_X/DIP_INC_Y + 1) dips are tested in the Y direction,
 from -DIP_MAX_Y to +DIP_MAX_Y.
 
 Computer time is roughly proportional to the number of dips tested in the
 X direction times the number of dips tested in the Y direction.

Help.Tip: Dip increment in X direction to use in the dip search calculation.
Help.Text:
ranline - DIP_INC_X
Dip increment in X direction to use in the dip search calculation.
 
 Dip increments are in ms/trace in the X direction.
 
 A total of (2*DIP_X/DIP_INC_X + 1) dips are tested in the X direction,
 from -DIP_MAX_X to +DIP_MAX_X.
 
 Computer time is roughly proportional to the number of dips tested in the
 X direction times the number of dips tested in the Y direction.
 
 This value is calculated from the Nyquist frequency and the SEARCH_X
 parameter to keep from aliasing the dip search on the farthest traces.

Help.Tip: Dip increment in Y direction to use in the dip search calculation.
Help.Text:
ranline - DIP_INC_Y
Dip increment in Y direction to use in the dip search calculation.
 
 Dip increments are in ms/trace in the Y direction.
 
 A total of (2*DIP_X/DIP_INC_Y + 1) dips are tested in the Y direction,
 from -DIP_MAX_Y to +DIP_MAX_Y.
 
 Computer time is roughly proportional to the number of dips tested in the
 X direction times the number of dips tested in the Y direction.
 
 This value is calculated from the Nyquist frequency and the SEARCH_Y
 parameter to keep from aliasing the dip search on the farthest traces.

Help.Tip: Total number of dips to be tested in X direction.
Help.Text:
ranline - NXDIPS
Total number of dips to be tested in X direction.

Help.Tip: Total number of dips to be tested in Y direction.
Help.Text:
ranline - NYDIPS
Total number of dips to be tested in Y direction.

Help.Tip: Maximum X search distance of useable trace from output location.
Help.Text:
ranline - SEARCH_X
Maximum X search distance of useable trace from output location.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 
 This is in units of the X header word values.

Help.Tip: Maximum Y search distance of useable trace from output location.
Help.Text:
ranline - SEARCH_Y
Maximum Y search distance of useable trace from output location.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 
 This is in units of the Y header word values.

Help.Tip: Unit size of the X header word values in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
ranline - FEET_X
Unit size of the X header word values in feet or meters.
 
 Default = nil
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Unit size of the Y header word values in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
ranline - FEET_Y
Unit size of the Y header word values in feet or meters.
 
 Default = nil
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Status of the specified random line coordinates.
Help.Text:
ranline - COORDS_INFO
Status of the specified random line coordinates.
 
 This information summarizes the status of the random line coordinates
 whech are specified on the "Random Line Coordinates" screen.  That screen
 should be visited to insure that the specified coordinates are correct,
 or that the status of the file which specifies the coordinates is acceptable.

Help.Tip: Message regarding number of requested diagnostic files.
Help.Text:
ranline - MESSAGE
Message regarding number of requested diagnostic files.
 
 This information refers to the diagnostic files requested on the
 "Diagnostic Output Files" screen.  That screen should be visited
 to insure that the requests are correct and the status of each
 requested file is acceptable.

Help.Tip: Base name for pathnames for diagnostic trace output files.
Help.Text:
ranline - BASENAME
Base name for pathnames for diagnostic trace output files.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 
 This basename is used to create path names for files which will contain
 diagnostic traces.  This basename must not include a filename extension.

Help.Tip: Whether to save edge detection traces to PATH_MEDGE.
Help.Text:
ranline - SAVE_MEDGE
Whether to save edge detection traces to PATH_MEDGE.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES or NO

Help.Tip: Pathname for Meek edge detection traces.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_MEDGE
Pathname for Meek edge detection traces.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 
 One edge detection trace will be output to the file for each trace processed.
 The file will be an 8-bit file.
 
 These traces are calculated from moving gathers centered on each input trace.

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_MEDGE.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_MEDGE_INFO
Status of PATH_MEDGE.

Help.Tip: Whether to save edge detection traces to PATH_SEDGE.
Help.Text:
ranline - SAVE_SEDGE
Whether to save edge detection traces to PATH_SEDGE.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES or NO

Help.Tip: Pathname for semblance edge detection traces.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_SEDGE
Pathname for semblance edge detection traces.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 
 One edge detection trace will be output to the file for each trace processed.
 The file will be an 8-bit file.
 
 These traces are calculated from moving gathers centered on each input trace.

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_SEDGE.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_SEDGE_INFO
Status of PATH_SEDGE.

Help.Tip: Whether to save mixed traces to PATH_MIXED.
Help.Text:
ranline - SAVE_MIXED
Whether to save mixed traces to PATH_MIXED.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES or NO

Help.Tip: Pathname for mixed traces.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_MIXED
Pathname for mixed traces.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 
 One mixed trace will be output to the file for each trace processed.
 The file will be an 8-bit file.
 
 These traces are calculated from moving gathers centered on each input trace.

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_MIXED.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_MIXED_INFO
Status of PATH_MIXED.

Help.Tip: Whether to save semblance traces to PATH_SEMB.
Help.Text:
ranline - SAVE_SEMB
Whether to save semblance traces to PATH_SEMB.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES or NO

Help.Tip: Pathname for diagnostic traces of semblance values found.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_SEMB
Pathname for diagnostic traces of semblance values found.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 
 One semblance trace will be output to the file for each trace processed.
 Semblances are between zero and one.
 The file will be an 8-bit file.

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_SEMB.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_SEMB_INFO
Status of PATH_SEMB.

Help.Tip: Whether to save dip traces to PATH_XDIP.
Help.Text:
ranline - SAVE_XDIP
Whether to save dip traces to PATH_XDIP.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES or NO

Help.Tip: Pathname for diagnostic traces of dips found in the X direction.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_XDIP
Pathname for diagnostic traces of dips found in the X direction.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 
 One dip trace will be output to the file for each trace processed.
 Dips are in milliseconds per trace.
 The file will be an 8-bit file.
 
 The traces will be dead if dip searches are not done in the X direction.

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_XDIP.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_XDIP_INFO
Status of PATH_XDIP.

Help.Tip: Whether to save dip traces to PATH_YDIP.
Help.Text:
ranline - SAVE_YDIP
Whether to save dip traces to PATH_YDIP.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES or NO

Help.Tip: Pathname for diagnostic traces of dips found in the Y direction.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_YDIP
Pathname for diagnostic traces of dips found in the Y direction.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 
 One dip trace will be output to the file for each trace processed.
 Dips are in milliseconds per trace.
 The file will be an 8-bit file.
 
 The traces will be dead if dip searches are not done in the Y direction.
 (This is the case for the 2D SDIP process.)

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_YDIP.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_YDIP_INFO
Status of PATH_YDIP.

Help.Tip: Whether to save original moving gathers to PATH_ORIG.
Help.Text:
ranline - SAVE_ORIG
Whether to save original moving gathers to PATH_ORIG.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES or NO

Help.Tip: Pathname for diagnostic traces of original gathers.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_ORIG
Pathname for diagnostic traces of original gathers.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 
 These are the original moving gathers used for doing the dip search.
 One moving gather will be output to the file for each trace processed.
 Each moving gather contains all of the traces used to do a dip search
 for each trace processed.  Each moving gather will contain
 (2*NUM_TR_DIP_X + 1) times (2*NUM_TR_DIP_Y + 1) traces.
 
 This file can be very large.
 The file will be an 8-bit file.

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_ORIG.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_ORIG_INFO
Status of PATH_ORIG.

Help.Tip: Whether to save flattened moving gathers to PATH_FLAT.
Help.Text:
ranline - SAVE_FLAT
Whether to save flattened moving gathers to PATH_FLAT.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES or NO

Help.Tip: Pathname for diagnostic traces of flattened gathers.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_FLAT
Pathname for diagnostic traces of flattened gathers.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 
 These are the moving gathers as they have been flattened using the results
 of the dip search.  One moving gather will be output to the file for each
 trace processed.  Each moving gather contains all of the traces used to do
 a dip search for each trace processed.  Each moving gather will contain
 (2*NUM_TR_DIP_X + 1) times (2*NUM_TR_DIP_Y + 1) traces.
 
 This file can be very large.
 The file will be an 8-bit file.
 
 The traces will be same as original gathers if dip searches are not done.

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_FLAT.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_FLAT_INFO
Status of PATH_FLAT.

Help.Tip: Whether to save middle traces to PATH_MIDDLE.
Help.Text:
ranline - SAVE_MIDDLE
Whether to save middle traces to PATH_MIDDLE.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES or NO

Help.Tip: Pathname for middle trace of each moving gather.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_MIDDLE
Pathname for middle trace of each moving gather.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 
 One trace will be output to the file for each trace processed.
 The file will be an 8-bit file.
 
 Each trace output will be the trace from the moving gather which is the
 closest to the output trace location.  Therefore each trace should be the
 same as an original input trace.

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_MIDDLE.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATH_MIDDLE_INFO
Status of PATH_MIDDLE.

Help.Tip: Choose PATHNAME using a file selection dialog box.
Help.Text:
ranline - SELECT_PATHNAME
Choose PATHNAME using a file selection dialog box.

Help.Tip: Name of file containing X and Y coordinates along random lines.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATHNAME
Name of file containing X and Y coordinates along random lines.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = valid input file
 
 If this file is specified, X and Y coordinates will be read from the
 file instead of using the values in arrays X_COORD and Y_COORD.
 
 This file must be a CPS self defining file (or a foreign file) containing
 at least two columns of numbers, with X coordinates in the first column
 and Y coordinates in the second column, residing in the first section
 on the file.

Help.Tip: Status of PATHNAME.
Help.Text:
ranline - PATHNAME_INFO
Status of PATHNAME.

Help.Tip: List of X coordinates along random lines.
Help.Text:
ranline - X_COORD
List of X coordinates along random lines.
 
 Default = none
 Allowed = real
 
 X_COORD and Y_COORD are the X and Y coordinates of interpolated random
 lines through 3-D data.  The random lines are connected or separate line
 segments.  All units are the same as the units in HDR_X and HDR_Y.
 If (Xi,Yi) = (0,0), that point is not used, and the previous and following
 line segments are not connected.
 
 For example, given  X_COORD = X1,X2,X3,0,X5,X6
                and  Y_COORD = Y1,Y2,Y3,0,Y5,Y6 :
         (X1,Y1) = beginning of first straight line segment.
         (X2,Y2) = end of first line segment and beginning of second.
         (X3,Y3) = end of second line segment.
         (X5,Y5) = beginning of third line segment.
         (X6,Y6) = end of third line segment.

Help.Tip: List of Y coordinates along random lines.
Help.Text:
ranline - Y_COORD
List of Y coordinates along random lines.
 
 Default = none
 Allowed = real
 
 X_COORD and Y_COORD are the X and Y coordinates of interpolated random
 lines through 3-D data.  The random lines are connected or separate line
 segments.  All units are the same as the units in HDR_X and HDR_Y.
 If (Xi,Yi) = (0,0), that point is not used, and the previous and following
 line segments are not connected.
 
 For example, given  X_COORD = X1,X2,X3,0,X5,X6
                and  Y_COORD = Y1,Y2,Y3,0,Y5,Y6 :
         (X1,Y1) = beginning of first straight line segment.
         (X2,Y2) = end of first line segment and beginning of second.
         (X3,Y3) = end of second line segment.
         (X5,Y5) = beginning of third line segment.
         (X6,Y6) = end of third line segment.

Help.Tip: Press this button to plot the coordinates.
Help.Text:
ranline - PLOT
Press this button to plot the coordinates.
 
 This button will pop up a gnuplot plot of the (X_COORD,Y_COORD) coordinates
 of the random lines.  To update this plot after changing these coordinates,
 you can simply press the REPLOT button.  To delete this plot and open up
 a new plot, simply press this PLOT button again.  To pop down the plot,
 simply choose Close on the window manager pulldown menu (upper left corner
 of the Gnuplot popup).

Help.Tip: Press this button to plot the coordinates.
Help.Text:
ranline - REPLOT
Press this button to plot the coordinates.
 
 This button will replot the (X_COORD,Y_COORD) coordinates using the same
 gnuplot plot previously used (or a new one if none is currently open).
 To update this plot after changing these coordinates, you can simply press
 this REPLOT button again.  To delete this plot and open up a new plot,
 simply press the PLOT button.  To pop down the plot, simply choose Close
 on the window manager pulldown (upper left corner of the Gnuplot popup).

Help.Tip: Button that removes this process parameter screen.
Help.Text:
ranline - CLOSE
Button that removes this process parameter screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Appears only on the view-only process parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
Help.Text:
ranline - OK
Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values, runs the parameter traps and removes
 the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
Help.Text:
ranline - APPLY
Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps but does
 not remove the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
Help.Text:
ranline - CANCEL
Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =

Help.Tip: Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
Help.Text:
ranline - RESET
Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that sets the parameters back to their values when the screen appeared
 or to their last applied value.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
Help.Text:
ranline - PROCESSLISTLEFT
Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the previous process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
Help.Text:
ranline - PROCESSLIST
Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Menu that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to any chosen process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
Help.Text:
ranline - PROCESSLISTRIGHT
Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the next process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
Help.Text:
ranline - PROJECTDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as Project Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of Project Defaults for a project.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
Help.Text:
ranline - USERDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as User Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of User Defaults for a userid.

Help.Tip: Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
Help.Text:
ranline - HELP
Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 The Help Window allows access to three kinds of help:  Parameter Help, CPS
 Process Help and Application (CFE) Help.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                         C P S   P R O C E S S
 
 Name       : RANLINE                    (random line)
 Category   : miscellaneous
 Written    : 1989-08-17   by: Tom Stoeckley
 Revised    : 2006-12-04   by: Tom Stoeckley
 Maturity   : production
 Purpose    : Trace interpolation from random 3D locations to a random line.
 Portability: No known limitations.
 Parallel   : No.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          GENERAL DESCRIPTION
 
 This process can be used to select interpolated random lines out of 3-D
 data sets, with optional X-Y dip search.  This process generates diagonal
 lines (or connected or disconnected straight or bent line segments), with
 evenly spaced traces along the lines.  Each output trace is interpolated
 from neighboring traces within a bin rectangle centered at the output trace
 location.  Dip searches are performed in the (X,Y) directions.
 
 This process is intended to operate on stacked or migrated data.  Although
 such data is usually arranged on a regular grid, this process has no such
 requirement.
 
 This process uses the SDIPUTIL primitive to do the dip search and
 calculate the output traces.
 
 This process contains a subset of the capabilities of the old TERP process.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                         DETAILS OF OPERATION
 
 1. Within each window, the MAX_SEARCH nearest traces within distances
    SEARCH_X and SEARCH_Y of the output trace location are used to
    perform a semblance dip search to determine which dip has the maximum
    semblance.  Up to a maximum of (2*DIP_MAX_X + 1) times (2*DIP_MAX_Y + 1)
    dips are tested.  The dip with the maximum semblance is referred to as
    the dominant dip.  Each window length is WIN_LEN seconds long, and the
    windows move down the trace one sample at a time.
 
 2. For each window, the MAX_INTERP nearest traces within distances
    SEARCH_X and SEARCH_Y of the output trace location are weighted
    as described in ADVICE FOR USERS below and summed along the dominant
    dip to form an interpolated trace.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          ADVICE FOR USERS
 
  1. Parameter FRACMIX specifies the fractional mix performed during
     interpolation.
 
     FRACMIX=0 means a minimum amount of mixing is done, with all weights
     inversely proportional to "distance" from the trace output location,
     defined as SQRT([DX/SEARCH_X]**2 + [DY/SEARCH_Y]**2).  This is
     appropriate for straight interpolation.
 
     In the above definition for "distance", (DX,DY) is the (X,Y) distance
     of an individual trace from the trace output location, and
     (SEARCH_X,SEARCH_Y) is the maximum (X,Y) distance a trace can
     be from the trace output location to be used for dip search,
     interpolation, or mixing.
 
     FRACMIX=1.414 or larger means all traces used for interpolation
     will be weighted equally, regardless of their distances from the
     interpolated trace output location.  This would be a strong mix
     (equal-weight stack along dips) rather than an interpolation.
 
     For example, FRACMIX=0.3 means that all traces within "distance"
     0.3 (as defined above) will have a weight corresponding to
     distance 0.3 (rather than a larger weight for shorter distance).
     This would be appropriate if you want to do some mixing while
     interpolating, so that an individual trace that may happen to
     lie at the trace output location will not get all the weight.
 
  2. Traces will contribute to a bin (i.e. used for dip search,
     interpolation, or mixing) only if they fall within distance
     (SEARCH_X,SEARCH_Y) from the trace output location.  A trace can
     contribute to more than one bin (i.e. the bins can overlap).
     However, MAX_SEARCH and MAX_INTERP limit the number of traces that
     can contribute to a bin by deleting excess traces that are
     the farthest from the trace output location.
 
  3. Arrays X_COORD and Y_COORD specify the (X,Y) coordinates of
     interpolated random lines through 3-D data.  The random lines are
     connected or separate line segments.  All units are the
     same as the units in HDR_X and HDR_Y.  if (Xi,Yi)=(0,0), that
     point is not used, and the previous and following line segments
     are not connected.
 
     For example, given  X_COORD = X1,X2,X3,0,X5,X6
                    and  Y_COORD = Y1,Y2,Y3,0,Y5,Y6 :
        (X1,Y1) = beginning of first straight line segment.
        (X2,Y2) = end of first line segment and beginning of second.
        (X3,Y3) = end of second line segment.
        (X5,Y5) = beginning of third line segment.
        (X6,Y6) = end of third line segment.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                             REVISION HISTORY
 
     Date        Author     Description
     ----        ------     -----------
 14. 2006-12-04  Stoeckley  Replace pc_register_tab_group w HelpSection line.
 13. 2006-08-24  D. Glover  Added NULLIFY statements for Intel compiler.
 12. 2006-06-20  Stoeckley  Add pc_register_tab_group for SeisSpace.
 11. 2002-09-11  Stoeckley  Add help for PLOT pushbutton; also allow optional
                             reuse of the same gnuplot for subsequent plots
                             rather than closing the old and and opening a
                             new gnuplot; move most of the gnuplot logic
                             to the new primitive GPLOT.
 10. 2002-09-06  Stoeckley  Add gnuplot capability to front end.
  9. 2002-08-26  Stoeckley  Improve error printouts; add warnings for
                             parameters which appear to be incorrect.
  8. 2002-08-05  Stoeckley  Converted from the TERP process in the old system;
                             previous history refers to the TERP process.
  7. 1999-02-22  Goodger    Begin using the fortran90 compiler.
  6. 1993-09-20  Stoeckley  Change FILE to type integer to match IBLK.
  5. 1992-02-26  Peterson   New option to input SEGX and SEGY values from
                             a file.
  4. 1992-01-08  Peterson   Transfer FEET(3) array through TERPBEG and
                             ENTRY TERPCC2 calling sequence for METHOD=
                             CLOD.  New cft couldn't find FEET(3).
  3. 1989-06-02  Stoeckley  Change TERPFAST to version which will not
                             abort due to faulty compiler optimization,
                             and add alternate error return to a few
                             routines.
  2. 1989-06-21  Stoeckley  Change parameter GATHER to parameter OUTPUT,
                             with new option OUTPUT=SELECT.
  1. 1989-08-17  Stoeckley  Fix bug in parameter FRACMIX, and fix an
                             incorrect print statement.
